guide.title: Gentoo SELinux 2006.1 Upgrade Guide
guide.abstract: This guide describes the upgrade path from SELinux 2005.1 to 2006.1.

body.warn: The hardened profiles are not currently supported due to the unavailability of hardened glibc 2.4.
body.impo: The app-portage/portage-utils package will be needed in this install, please make sure it is installed. It can be removed at the end of the upgrade.
This upgrade should be performed in permissive mode as root/sysadm_r.
body.p: The 2006.1 SELinux policy is now based on the new SELinux Reference Policy, and new management infrastructure (libsemanage/semodule/semanage).
First switch your profile to the SELinux profile for your architecture:
body.pre:
# rm -f /etc/make.profile
x86: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/x86/2006.1 /etc/make.profile AMD64: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/amd64/2006.1 /etc/make.profile G3 PPC: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/ppc/ppc32/2006.1/G3 /etc/make.profile G4 PPC: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/ppc/ppc32/2006.1/G4 /etc/make.profile SPARC: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/sparc/sparc64/2006.1 /etc/make.profile

chapter.title: Merge new SELinux userland and base policy

body.p: The new policies require current SELinux userland components. Also, since the new reference policy has a new portage policy domain (portage_t.merge), we must temporarily force portage to use the old domain (portage_t) until the new selinux-base-policy is installed.
body.pre: # PORTAGE_T="portage_t" emerge -u1 libsepol libselinux libsemanage checkpolicy policycoreutils selinux-base-policy

body.p: New in 2006.1, users now have the choice between the strict policy and the targeted policy.
The old policy was strict; all processes are confined. Strict policy is suggested for servers. Gentoo does not support the strict policy on desktops.

The targeted policy differs with strict, as only network-facing services are confined and local users are unconfined. Gentoo only supports desktops with the targeted policy. This policy can also be used on servers.
Edit the /etc/selinux/config file to set the policy type.
body.pre:
# This file controls the state of SELinux on the system on boot.
# SELINUX can take one of these three values: # enforcing - SELinux security policy is enforced. # permissive - SELinux prints warnings instead of enforcing. # disabled - No SELinux policy is loaded. SELINUX=permissive (This should be set permissive for the remainder of the upgrade)
# SELINUXTYPE can take one of these two values: # targeted - Only targeted network daemons are protected. # strict - Full SELinux protection. SELINUXTYPE=strict (Set this as strict or targeted)

body.p: There was a problem with the old portage policies. When udev was merged, reference devices made in /lib/udev/devices were not able to be created, and instead regular files were created. These should be removed if they exist.
The system will still function correctly, but if you want to be sure, remerge udev.
Relabel the system, then reboot, and log in as root/sysadm_r and relabel the system again. Since the policy sources are no longer installed, relabeling can be done with the rlpkg tool.

pre.caption: rlpkg syntax for relabeling the system

body.p: If you previously had SELinux identities configured in your users file, there is a new way to manage this, see the SELinux Overview for more details.
There are several changes with SELinux that have been mentioned in this guide. Please refer to the SELinux Handbook for more information on these features and tools.
